choices.text: Pituitary tumor
Adrenal adenoma

questions.text: Most common cause of Cushing’s syndrome is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Exogenous corticosteroids

 

Option A:

 

The most frequent cause of Cushing's syndrome is the iatrogenic administration of exogenous corticosteroids. This can occur with prolonged use of oral, intravenous, or inhaled glucocorticoids for the treatment of various conditions such as asthma, autoimmune diseases, or after organ transplantation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: A pituitary adenoma that secretes adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) can cause Cushing's disease, which is a subset of Cushing's syndrome. This is the most common cause of endogenous Cushing's syndrome, but overall less common than the exogenous form caused by taking corticosteroid medications.

 

Option C: An adrenal adenoma is a benign tumor of the adrenal gland that can autonomously secrete cortisol. It's a less common cause of Cushing's syndrome compared to exogenous steroid use and pituitary tumors but should be considered, especially when ACTH levels are low.

 

Option D: Adrenal carcinomas are rare but can also cause Cushing's syndrome by secreting excessive amounts of cortisol. They are more aggressive than adenomas and can be associated with a worse prognosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exogenous corticosteroids are the most common cause of Cushing's syndrome, primarily due to the widespread use of corticosteroid medications for a variety of medical conditions.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1115

questions.text: Most common site of pheochromocytoma after adrenal gland is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Organs of Zuckerkandl

 

Option B:

 

The organs of Zuckerkandl are a collection of chromaffin cells located at the bifurcation of the aorta near the origin of the inferior mesenteric artery. These are the most common extra-adrenal site for pheochromocytomas since they originate from the same embryonic tissue as the adrenal medulla where chromaffin cells are most abundant.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: The hilum of the kidney is an area where the renal artery enters and the renal vein and ureter exit. While it is close to the adrenal glands, it is not a common site for extra-adrenal pheochromocytomas, which are tumors that arise from chromaffin cells typically found in the adrenal medulla.

 

Option C: While chromaffin tissue can be found along the sympathetic chain in the neck, pheochromocytomas are not commonly found in this location.

 

Option D: Pheochromocytomas can occur in the urinary bladder, but it is an uncommon site. When they do occur in this location, they can cause symptoms such as hypertension, palpitations, and headache during micturition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Organs of Zuckerkandl are the most common extra-adrenal pheochromocytoma.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1130

choices.text: Bilateral in 10% of cases

questions.text: True about adrenal pheochromocytoma is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bilateral in 10% of cases

 

Option C:

 

Pheochromocytomas are bilateral in about 10% of cases, particularly when associated with genetic conditions such as Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2 or von Hippel-Lindau disease. In sporadic cases, they are more often unilateral.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Adrenal pheochromocytomas are typically chromaffin positive, meaning they stain positively for chromaffin, which is indicative of catecholamine-secreting cells. These tumors arise from chromaffin cells in the adrenal medulla.

 

Option B: While pheochromocytomas can be malignant, most are benign. The malignancy rate is estimated to be about 10% in adrenal pheochromocytomas. Malignancy is usually determined by the presence of metastasis rather than histological features.

 

Option D: This statement is incorrect because unilateral pheochromocytomas are much more common than 10%. The majority of pheochromocytomas are unilateral.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While most adrenal pheochromocytomas are benign and unilateral, they can be bilateral in 10% of cases, especially in hereditary syndromes.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1127

choices.text: Renal cell carcinoma

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of episodic headaches, palpitations, and sweating. Physical examination reveals elevated blood pressure and a palpable abdominal mass. Which of the following tumors is most likely to exhibit the "rule of 10" characteristic?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pheochromocytoma 

 

Option A:

 

Pheochromocytomas are tumors of the adrenal medulla that secrete catecholamines and follow the "rule of 10s": approximately 10% are malignant, 10% are bilateral, 10% are extra-adrenal, 10% occur in children, and 10% are not associated with hypertension.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Oncocytomas are benign renal epithelial tumors that typically do not follow the "rule of 10s". They are usually asymptomatic and are often found incidentally during imaging for other conditions.

 

Option C:  Lymphomas are cancers of the lymphatic system and do not follow the "rule of 10s". They have various subtypes with differing presentations and prognoses.

 

Option D: Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is the most common type of kidney cancer in adults and does not adhere to the "rule of 10s". RCC has different subtypes with varying clinical behaviors and genetic associations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pheochromocytoma is classically described by the "rule of 10s", which can be helpful in remembering the characteristics of this tumor for diagnosis and management decisions.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1127

questions.text: Which one of the following is not seen in pheochromocytoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Diarrhea

 

Option D:

 

The dominant clinical manifestation of pheochromocytoma is hypertension. 

 

Diarrhea is not a classic symptom of pheochromocytoma. While catecholamines can affect gastrointestinal motility and secretion, they are more likely to cause symptoms such as abdominal pain or constipation rather than diarrhea.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Hypertension is a hallmark sign of pheochromocytoma and can be sustained or paroxysmal due to episodic catecholamine secretion by the tumor.

 

Option B: Episodic palpitations are a common symptom of pheochromocytoma due to episodic release of catecholamines, particularly norepinephrine, which stimulates the heart and causes increased contractility and heart rate.

 

Option C: Weight loss is frequently seen in pheochromocytoma patients. The excess catecholamines can increase metabolism and cause a hyperadrenergic state, leading to weight loss even in the presence of a good appetite.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While hypertension, episodic palpitations, and weight loss are common in pheochromocytoma, diarrhea is not typically associated with this condition.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1127

choices.text: Benign and malignant thyroid cancers
Benign and malignant pheochromocytoma
Benign and malignant liver tumors
Benign and malignant renal tumors

questions.text: Mitotic figures and giant cells are seen in which of the following tumor?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Benign and malignant pheochromocytoma

 

Option B:

 

Pheochromocytomas are difficult to diagnose exclusively from the histological appearance. Cellular and nuclear pleomorphism, including the presence of giant cells, and mitotic figures are often seen in benign pheochromocytomas. So, the definitive diagnosis of malignancy in pheochromocytomas is based exclusively on the presence of metastases.

 

Pheochromocytomas, whether benign or malignant, can exhibit cellular and nuclear pleomorphism, which includes the presence of giant cells and mitotic figures. The presence of these features does not correlate with malignancy, as malignancy in pheochromocytoma is defined by the presence of metastasis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Thyroid cancers can indeed present with mitotic figures, especially in more aggressive forms such as anaplastic thyroid carcinoma. However, giant cells are particularly characteristic of certain inflammatory conditions such as subacute thyroiditis, rather than thyroid neoplasms.

 

Option C: Benign and malignant liver tumors \ such as hepatocellular carcinoma can show mitotic figures, indicating a high proliferative rate. However, giant cells are more typical of specific liver pathologies such as giant cell hepatitis, not necessarily of benign or malignant liver tumors.

 

Option D: In renal tumors, mitotic figures are also indicative of a higher grade of malignancy, especially in clear cell renal carcinoma. Giant cells are not a characteristic feature of common benign or malignant renal tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The histological presence of mitotic figures and giant cells in pheochromocytomas is not indicative of malignancy; instead, malignancy is confirmed by the presence of metastatic disease.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1127

choices.text: 10% are extra adrenal

questions.text: Which of the following is not part of the “rule of 10” in pheochromocytoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 10% are symptomatic

 

Option D:

 

This statement is not part of the "rule of 10" related to pheochromocytoma. In fact, most patients with pheochromocytoma are symptomatic, presenting with a classic triad of headaches, sweating, and tachycardia, along with episodic hypertension.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: In the context of pheochromocytoma, approximately 10% of tumors can be found bilaterally, often associated with hereditary conditions such as Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia types 2A and 2B, von Hippel-Lindau disease, and neurofibromatosis type 1.

 

Option B: Pheochromocytomas are usually benign, but about 10% can be malignant. Malignancy is determined by the presence of metastases rather than the histological appearance of the primary tumor.

 

Option C: Around 10% of pheochromocytomas are located outside of the adrenal glands, commonly in the abdomen in locations like the organ of Zuckerkandl. These are termed paragangliomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "rule of 10" in pheochromocytoma refers to the observation that approximately:

 

  1. 10% of pheochromocytomas are extra-adrenal.
  2. 10% of pheochromocytomas are bilateral, affecting both adrenal glands.
  3. 10% of pheochromocytomas are malignant.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1127
